reviews.content: Wasn't crazy about the sherried aspect of this bottling initially, but after it's about halfway done, it started to improve dram-atically. Now there's more of the bourbon maturation and the maritime, sea-breezy character coming through. Still can't hold a candle to the 17-year-old it's supposed to replace, but there's certainly enough here to make me not regret buying a bottle. With enough air, the nose really is something to behold. Initial score: 85 pointsAfter some aeration: 87 points.Let's settle for the middle.
reviews.nose: (with a lot of air, it actually reaches 88 points)

reviews.content: It's oily, iodized, salty, it looks like fresh fish, you think you can smell the scales. The tide, the sand, the sea spray, a little seaweed, the kelp. Behind it, the influence of bourbon and a welcome, albeit light, touch of sherry. Moist leather, almonds and walnuts, orchard fruits, Conference pears and Granny Smith apples. In the mouth, coarse salt, vanilla, white plum, sweet caramel, salted butter. The spices rise slowly, without being overpowering. Fairly long finish, on sandy and limestone soil. Lemon zest. Very nice balance offered by this 15 year old. Young enough for us to feel the iodine intensity, but old enough to offer a beautiful complexity. https://ilikesky2020.blogspot.com/2020/10/old-pulteney-15-yo-maritime-malt.html

A whisky from high in the north of Scotland. Pulteney Distillery is located in the port town of Wick on Scotland's north coast. Even if it is no longer the northernmost Mainland Distillery - the whiskys of the distillery are considered maritime-strong malts. The original bottlings are named Old Pulteney. This is 15 years old, has 46.0% vol. and should be uncolored and unchill filtered. In any case, the color has a beautiful, natural gold tone. In the WhiskyJason Blind Tasting he achieved a decent third place - with me and with the other participants. www.glen-efze.de
reviews.nose: The aroma is initially not maritime, but fruity with ripe, juicy fruits, sweetness and concentrated plum juice, which has a sour component in addition to the sticky sweetness. This is a very pleasant aroma, wine gums flash and then there is a maritime note from the background with a touch of bitterness and freshness, which can come from the wood and alcohol. Over time, the fruit also blends into a tart herbal note with the scent of Scottish heather (but no burnt peat, the whisky is not smoky) and a seaweed breeze off the beach.
reviews.taste: Also in the taste comes the sticky plum juice, then the alcohol pushes and the flavors become drier and woodier. Overall, however, the aromas are not present for long and should be more pronounced and powerful for a maritime malt. There's a distinct bitterness that doesn't come from the wood alone. With further sips, the fruit note becomes stronger again and the bitterness recedes into the background, herbs and wine gums are present, vanilla fills the mouth and some milk chocolate is added. This is actually quite tasty.
reviews.finish: In the finish, the bitterness is dominant at first, which quickly becomes weaker. Then the aftertaste of red British wine gums and vanilla remains in the mouth. This is a drinkable whisky that strikes a nice balance between the ex-bourbon base with vanilla flavors and the sweet and sour plum fruitiness from the sherry cask. A few more active casks would certainly have given it more incisive aromas, but even so, it holds up well in a northern port city. At least on sunny afternoons. But when the storm comes, other whiskys have to be on the table...

A fine dram! But I liked the old range better.

Old Pulteney 15 yo, 46%, Sep 2021. Pale golden. Aroma is banoffee, spiritous caramelised notes, caramelised wood char, first fill ex-bourbon cask mixed with refill. The spirit behind all that seems pretty much neutral. There's a faint candy floss vibe. Watery mouthfeel. Taste is easy and soft, really easy-going indeed, no rough edges to this whatsoever - mild with impressions of very milky coffee, bourbon biscuits and Oreos, just the very softest woodiness. The subtle chocolatiness suggests the use of at least some decent sherry casks, but isn't too sherry focused which is my preference. The aroma eventually picks up that sherried chocolatiness over time. Some eggnog. Nutmeg spice. A solid whisky all told – perfectly enjoyable. 3.55/85=========Old Pulteney 15 Year Old, 46%. 30ml sample at home, Aug 2024. Dark dull amber. Aroma has dark apple juice, apple crumble, hints of guava and woodchip, buttery oak. Good. Body is very lightly oily. Taste is rock salt on arrival, vague sweet oak suggesting vanilla or butter, finishes a bit limp and watery but with some burnt char and salt. Pretty good aroma but then quite simple and a bit wishy-washy on the palate. Based on this showing, it’s a decent enough whisky that would not inspire a bottle purchase. 3.45/82

Well put-together, if a little thin and weird. There’s just a little bit of sherry influence, but I think it works. There’s some decent complexity, the development is quite nice, and the age shows. I can’t believe it, but I think it’s a little too salty for me. There are some off notes as well (like that chlorine) that pop in and out, which hurt my experience a little, but weren’t too bad. I thankfully didn’t have anything close to the horrible experience I had with the 12 year thankfully. Still, I was a little salted-out by this one. I’m confident that lots of other people will enjoy this more than I did.Nose: Sweet and salty. Sugary, almost crystallized dried fruit: dates, pineapple, and banana. Light cereals and honey. Nature Valley bars! The kind dipped in the sugary caramel stuff. Just the tiniest hint of smoke. It’s quite salty, with sea breeze and even a bit of chlorine. The fruit fills out a bit more as it sits in the glass.Palate: Light texture, but quite oily. A bit hit of salt up front, followed by manuka honey and dried fruit. A bit of rum-y banana funk here, along with mango and pineapple. Develops into toast and walnuts, followed by oak and a hit of black pepper. There’s a little bit of peat here too, mixed in with that pepper. A bit of a slaty mineral note on the back end, along with sugared raisins. It never loses that salty edge.Finish: Long, and sweet-and-salty again. Lots of honey. Salt and pepper. Dried apple slices, a bit of lychee, and nuts. A bag of trail mix, maybe.

A very beautiful nose is continued on the palate with the formidable bourbon and sherry barrel interplay, supplemented by bakery sweetness and delicate maritime seasoning. Is for me on at least one stage with the 17er. The nice thing is: You can enjoy this malt "just like that" and you can also "disassemble it in its entirety". If you like Glenfarclas without sherry turbo (ie the 25's from the standard range or older 4th-Fill-Casks), you should also like this malt.
reviews.nose: Clear, maritime, coastal spicy. And still with the shot of sherry and bakery flavors. So to speak the 17er, the direction 25er-Pulteney goes. If the 2006 "pure Bourbonpulteney pure", this is now the (also for the 17er) also typical "crystal clear-maritime Pulteney-Bourbon-and-Sherryfass-Melange".
reviews.taste: Very enjoyable! Crystal clear, now with sherry sweets and bakery that goes into vanilla. Everything is beautifully mint fresh primed with the pulteneytypischen 46%. The oak comes too. Then again sherry, cinnamon and a pinch of sea salt. Amazingly full for his 15 years and then again slightly in enjoyment. The balance between sherry and bourbon keg is absolutely successful.
reviews.finish: In the medium-long finish, then the oak again with some espresso.

reviews.nose: Much richer than the 12YO pal. Waxy apple, floral, sweet woody scent, ripen pear, honey, chocolate, salty but not briny. Spicy and milky in the emptied glass.
reviews.taste: Medium body, Delicately sweet but lasted for a while. vanilla, candle wax, spices. Sour punch before flowing into the throat. Pepper attacks.
reviews.finish: Almost long, cardboard, pear drop, vanilla, wood spices, sweetness persists.

This is very pleasant! I'm quite surprised and pleased with this. I could drink this every day. Note: I let this sit for about 40 minutes first.

reviews.taste: Warm freshly stewed orchard fruits, a nice sea breeze, lightly toasted then creamed nuts, vanilla ice cream wax, and white pepper.
reviews.finish: At first, the same lingering notes as the palate only with the orchard fruits becoming fresher and less stewed, then fresh almonds and flowers take over at the very end.

reviews.content: A wonderfully smooth summer whisky that I'd love to drink more often. Simple and delicious.
reviews.nose: A deliciously sweet and salty aroma, almost like salted caramel. There's sea air, peach, and brown sugar. There's also some chocolate, pineapple, and walnut in the background.
reviews.taste: Wonderfully smooth and approachable. It opens with flavors of dried fruit, raisins, and seaweed. This is followed by notes of milk chocolate, nutmeg, and orange. In the background, there are hints of walnut and cinnamon.
reviews.finish: Medium to short, with flavors of tobacco, dark chocolate, and sherry emerging. In the background, there are hints of salted caramel fudge.

reviews.content: A really great, varied and maritime malt. Is complex enough for me to explore for a while, but not an overly complex board. You can also just drink with friends all evening long. Leave a little time in the glass, after 10 minutes it becomes much more complex.
reviews.nose: very spicy, then sweet and fruity influence of the sherry cask. Little sea breeze. Sherry influence increases with time in the glass.
reviews.taste: Spicy again, cinnamon and cardamom "spiciness", cocoa / tart dark chocolate and then the sweetness. Dark fruits only very briefly, then more honey sweetness. Once Christmas in a glass. Maritime influence not pronounced here.
reviews.finish: medium length, maritime, with a slight sweetness in the background.

reviews.content: More interesting than 10 and 12 yo. Still the same type. Dryer, vegetative, vanilla. But there is more spice in the taste, more roughness. But in the aftertaste, again quite an unpleasant bitterness for me. It is a drinkable whisky, you can easily do without a bottle.

NOSEBanana malted milkshake, honey graham, vanilla frosting, nuts and a light bit of baking spice and lemon peel.Delicate, but not weak, this is a nice, relaxing, and easy aroma I can happily sit and sniff.PALATEBanana malted milkshake, honey graham, waxy vanilla frosting, dried orchard fruit, roasted nuts, baking spice, toffee and touches of leather and hay.Woah. The aroma does NOT give you much insight into the palate of this Old Pulteney 15. It’s so much richer and fuller.FINISHMed-long -> Waxy vanilla+banana, malt, earthy hay and graham fade to honied grahams.
I will definitely buy it again.
reviews.nose: Dried fruit, dark oak, vanilla, brown sugar, dark caramel, forest honey, seaweed, nutmeg and malt.
reviews.taste: A bag of dried fruits and dark aromas like a tea shop, followed by vanilla, milk chocolate, forest honey, nutmeg, seaweed and old wood.
reviews.finish: Very dry, old wood, dark sherry, dried fruits, espresso, nutmeg and dark chocolate.

reviews.content: Aroma: open, sweet ripe pear, honeycomb, flowering linden, vanilla, apple pie, white raisins. Over time, the fruit component becomes even sweeter, a ripe melon appears. In the background there are a few minerals, wet granite, a burnt piece of wood, a little salt. Taste: spicy ginger with honey, cloves, apple jam, lemonade shades, bitter zest, astringent wood, a hint of cocoa with milk. Finish: warming, tingling ginger, honey, sweet yellow fruits, exotic juice, zest, a little wood and finally minerality, seemed shorter than average. Score: 86 Bottom line: decent Pulteney, sweet, fruity, with a drop of minerality, such a strong average, quite worthy for 15 years.

reviews.nose: Starts with nice honey notes combined with a slight saltiness. Looks a bit waxy and heavier. In addition, fine juicy peach aromas and mandarins. At the very back comes a little oak spice. Reminds me of Scapa or Clynelish, even if the 15yo seems lighter and fruity.
reviews.taste: The first impression is milder than expected. A little later comes the spiciness with oak and beautiful maritime notes. Alternating with peaches and tangerines. A touch of salt and almond chocolate. Great compact mouthfeel.
reviews.finish: The finish is unfortunately not as strong as desired. Relatively mild and at most medium-long, some spice and warmth remain. No bitterness. Slightly sweet and a little drier.

reviews.content: Salted caramel, brown sugar, hint of cocoa.
Delicious milk chocolate with honey and pineapples, with delicate oak.

It's a good whisky, but I thought it didn't have to be aged in sherry casks. But I thought that if it was only in bourbon casks, there would be less difference from the 12 years, so I thought that sherry cask maturation was adopted.

reviews.finish: Long, just a little complex.

reviews.taste: The buttery, sweet note continues, with a little brioche, a little fresh white bread, honey, salt, candle wax. Very smooth and in good balance.
reviews.finish: Smooth, honeyed, no bitterness. Not especially complex, but very pleasant.

reviews.content: Nose: quite different with a lot of sherry influence, apple pie, glazed with burnt sugar, dried fruit, cinnamon, clove and a touch of vanilla. deep dark honey, sultana and spice. you can feel some ex-bourbon influence too in addition to the sherry finish which adds a nice depth.Palate: it’s lovely on the palate. with a nice sweetness, ripe orange, earth, salty, sweet, warming spices, Xmas cake , some chocolate, toffee and a hint of salt – lovely.Finish : Oak, chocolate, ripe orange marmalade, very nice wood notes, tea.Yummy stuff indeed. A very nice sherry oriented dram, with depth. Quite different from the 17 year old it ‘replaces’ , but still very good indeed. If I would be pressed I would choose the 17 by a really narrow margin, maybe since old habits are hard to rid o
